summary: This document is a series of emails from whistleblower Christopher J. Dilorio to various judges and SEC officials, alleging massive ongoing securities fraud, accounting fraud, and money laundering involving Virtu Financial (VIRT/NITE), Knight Capital (KCG), and their associates. Dilorio claims the SEC and SDNY are engaged in criminal obstruction to protect these entities and individuals like Rich Handler of Jefferies, while denying his whistleblower claims and covering up the true nature of their business: abusive naked short selling of OTC market shells to facilitate money laundering. This document is a lengthy whistleblower email from Christopher J. Dilorio to the SEC, detailing allegations of a massive, ongoing securities fraud and money laundering scheme involving penny stock shells, broker-dealers like Knight/NITE/Virtu, and entities like UBS, Hanover/Magna, and JMJ Financial. Dilorio accuses the SEC of criminal obstruction, using his whistleblower information to both bring and obstruct complaints while denying him compensation. The email references multiple prior TCRs (Tips, Complaints, and Referrals) and connects the scheme to figures like Michael Milken, Josh Sason, and various political and financial entities.

persons.name: Christopher J. Dilorio
persons.context: Author of the emails, making extensive allegations of securities fraud, accounting fraud, and money laundering involving Virtu Financial, Knight Capital, and others. Claims the SEC and SDNY are obstructing investigations.

persons.name: Cifu
persons.context: Referenced as the CEO of Virtu Financial (VIRT/NITE) who made admissions about the retail-driven revenue model and is implicated in balance sheet fraud and the orchestration of the VIRT/KCG merger.

persons.name: Rich Handler
persons.context: Alleged to have a corrupt relationship with the SEC and SDNY. Jefferies is implicated as a major shareholder in KCG and beneficiary of the fraudulent VIRT/KCG merger.

persons.name: Dan Kamensky
persons.context: Referenced as a defendant who received a plea deal allegedly due to Dilorio's information, but Dilorio claims exculpatory evidence is being withheld.

persons.name: Sean Galvin
persons.context: Identified as the third NITE/VIRT CFO in just over a year, accused of keeping the accounting fraud running.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Addressed in emails regarding the lack of investigation into Dilorio's allegations and the Dan Kamensky case.

persons.name: Judge Cave
persons.context: Addressed in emails regarding the corrupt relationship between the SEC, Handler, and Jefferies.

persons.name: Judge Jones
persons.context: Addressed in emails providing proof of SEC corruption related to the VIRT/KCG merger.

persons.name: Jay Clayton
persons.context: Accused of conflicts of interest due to his previous firm Sullivan & Cromwell's ties to NITE/VIRT, and of not recusing himself from relevant decisions.

persons.name: Glenn Hutchins
persons.context: Described as a friend of Jay Clayton and a former Blackstone employee who co-founded North Island, a top shareholder in NITE/VIRT, implicated in money laundering schemes.

persons.name: Robert Greifeld
persons.context: Former CEO of SunGard and NASDAQ, co-founded North Island with Hutchins. Implicated in self-dealing related to NASDAQ's purchase of the BRUT ECN from SunGard.

persons.name: Adena Friedman
persons.context: Current NASDAQ CEO who signed off on the transaction to purchase the BRUT ECN from SunGard.

persons.name: Jared Fishman
persons.context: Colleague of Jay Clayton at Sullivan & Cromwell, accused of playing a key role in keeping NITE/VIRT operational.

persons.name: Blostein
persons.context: Goldman Sachs analyst covering NITE/VIRT, accused of knowing about and omitting material facts regarding OTCM share volumes that drive revenue.

persons.name: Reppetto
persons.context: Referred to as a 'perma pumper' who asked questions on earnings calls. Implied to have a relationship with Jefferies/Handler.

persons.name: Fannon
persons.context: Mentioned alongside Reppetto in the context of Sell Side analysts covering NITE/VIRT.

persons.name: Joshie Sason
persons.context: Identified in Dilorio's TCRs, involved with Hanover/Magna in fraudulent schemes involving bogus notes and shell companies like CGFIA, IMDS, NewLead.

persons.name: Justin Keener
persons.context: Identified in Dilorio's TCRs, involved with JMJ in money laundering schemes, barred by FINRA as a 'Bad Actor', later involved with Blink Charging.

persons.name: Janey
persons.context: SEC official addressed in emails regarding the denial of Dilorio's whistleblower award and failure to produce the full record.

persons.name: Hoecker
persons.context: SEC Inspector General accused of corruption and preclusion from involvement due to conflicts.

persons.name: Norberg
persons.context: SEC official accused of creating extraordinary reasons for denying Dilorio's whistleblower award.

persons.name: Berger
persons.context: SEC official with whom Dilorio filed his 2013 TCR.

persons.name: Richard Best
persons.context: SEC NY official who brought a FINRA complaint against Brown Brothers Harriman based on Dilorio's information.

persons.name: Schwarzman
persons.context: Mentioned as someone Glenn Hutchins worked with at Blackstone.

persons.name: Justin W. Keener
persons.context: Operated JMJ Financial; charged by SEC in 2020 for unregistered penny stock dealing; alleged by Dilorio to be involved in money laundering shells.

persons.name: Joshua Sason
persons.context: Charged by SEC in 2019 for microcap frauds and unlawful offerings; linked by Dilorio to Hanover/Magna and money laundering shells like NewLead.

connections.description: Dilorio is a whistleblower who has submitted multiple TCRs and hundreds of emails alleging fraud, but claims the SEC has engaged in criminal obstruction and denied his awards.
Dilorio alleges a corrupt, criminal relationship exists between Handler/Jefferies and the SEC/SDNY, leading to obstruction of investigations and protection of NITE/VIRT.
Accused of orchestrating the fraudulent VIRT/KCG merger together, with Handler/Jefferies as a major KCG shareholder and beneficiary.
Colleagues at Sullivan & Cromwell; Fishman accused of playing a key role in keeping NITE/VIRT operational, implying Clayton's conflicts.
Co-founded North Island, which became a top shareholder in NITE/VIRT. Connected through SunGard and NASDAQ transactions.
Handler's Jefferies was the investment bank in the Kamensky case; Dilorio claims the SEC/SDNY are withholding exculpatory evidence to protect Handler/Jefferies.
Blostein is a Goldman Sachs analyst covering NITE/VIRT; Dilorio accuses him of omitting material facts about OTCM volumes after interactions with Cifu.
Keener operated under the name JMJ Financial, which is the subject of SEC enforcement action.
Sason is linked to entities Hanover and Magna, which are accused of fraudulent schemes involving penny stock shells.
Alleged by Dilorio to be the primary executing broker-dealers trading billions of shares in the same OTCM money laundering shells, facilitating the scheme.

connections: Note: The text implies numerous complex relationships between individuals, entities (like AQR, Milken network), and financial institutions. A complete list requires parsing the full document for all named individuals and their described interactions.

events.title: Knight Capital 'Glitch'
events.description: The trading 'glitch' at Knight Capital that resulted in massive losses, which Dilorio claims was a cover-up for the firm's insolvency due to illegal naked shorting.

events.title: VIRT/KCG Merger Closing
events.description: The $1.4 billion all-cash merger of KCG Holdings and Virtu Financial. Dilorio alleges it was fraudulent, with the SEC/Cifu/Handler writing down over $4 billion in leverage and using fraud assets to inflate the acquisition price.

events.title: Ongoing Balance Sheet Fraud
events.description: Dilorio points to Virtu Financial's Q4 2020 and Q3 2020 earnings reports as evidence of continuing balance sheet fraud, with inflated receivables representing naked short fails.

events.title: Dan Kamensky Plea Deal
events.description: Dan Kamensky receives a plea deal in a case involving the SEC/SDNY and Jefferies. Dilorio claims his information contributed to the deal but that exculpatory evidence is being withheld.

events.title: SEC Complaint Against SeeThroughEquity
events.description: The SEC brings a complaint against SeeThroughEquity, LLC for pump-and-dump schemes, which Dilorio notes was promoting Net Element (NETE), a company he had alerted the SEC about.

events.title: FINRA Bars Justin Keener
events.description: FINRA bars Justin Keener/JMJ as a 'Bad Actor' for failing to comply with investigations into money laundering schemes involving OTCM shells.

events.title: Dilorio's First Whistleblower Complaint
events.description: Christopher Dilorio filed his first whistleblower complaint with the SEC, alleging massive fraud centered on Knight Capital (NITE) and UBS.

events.title: Knight Capital "Glitch"
events.description: Knight Capital suffered a massive trading loss due to a software glitch, leading to an emergency bailout. Dilorio alleges this proved Knight's insolvency and involved fraudulent collateral.
Dilorio and Berger Montague submitted the Knight Capital TCR to the SEC.

events.title: SEC Oppenheimer AML Action
events.description: The SEC brought an administrative proceeding against Oppenheimer & Co. for anti-money laundering failures, which Dilorio claims was based on his information.

events.title: SEC Charges Justin Keener/JMJ Financial
events.description: The SEC filed a complaint against Justin W. Keener d/b/a JMJ Financial for acting as an unregistered penny stock dealer.

events: Note: Many other events are referenced (e.g., FINRA complaints, SEC actions against Sason, UBS DPA, various shell company registrations and revocations).
locations: Russia (mentioned in context of ruble-to-dollar conversion)
Santa Monica, California (HQ of New Concepts)
Miami Beach, Florida (residence of Justin Keener)
Denver, Colorado / Littleton, Colorado (related to CGFIA)
The Woodlands, Texas / Boca Raton, Florida (AppTech offices)
keyFacts: Christopher Dilorio, an SEC whistleblower, alleges Virtu Financial (VIRT/NITE) and its predecessor Knight Capital (KCG) are engaged in massive, ongoing accounting fraud and securities fraud, primarily through abusive naked short selling of OTC market shells to facilitate money laundering.

Dilorio claims the SEC and the SDNY are engaged in criminal obstruction to protect these entities and individuals like Rich Handler of Jefferies, with whom they have a corrupt relationship, while denying his whistleblower claims and awards.

The 2017 VIRT/KCG merger is alleged to be fraudulent, with the SEC, Cifu, and Handler writing down over $4 billion in leverage from KCG's balance sheet just before closing, using fraud assets to inflate the acquisition price while knowing KCG was insolvent.

Dilorio connects the fraud to a wider network involving former SEC Chairman Jay Clayton (conflicts with Sullivan & Cromwell), Glenn Hutchins, Robert Greifeld, NASDAQ, and money laundering schemes linked to Russian ruble conversion and OTCM shells.

The emails reference other alleged frauds Dilorio reported, including Net Element (NETE), which he describes as a money laundering/transaction laundering fraud connected to WireCard, and which received CARES Act funds.

The whistleblower, Christopher Dilorio, alleges a massive, ongoing scheme where broker-dealers like Knight/NITE/Virtu and UBS trade billions of shares in OTCM penny stock shells to facilitate money laundering and abusive naked shorting.

Dilorio claims the SEC has criminally obstructed investigations, using his whistleblower information to bring selective enforcement actions while protecting key players like NITE/Virtu and UBS, and denying him rightful compensation.
The 2012 Knight Capital "glitch" is presented not as an accident but as evidence of Knight's insolvency and balance sheet fraud, which the SEC allegedly helped cover up with a bailout.
Specific shells like CGFIA, IMDS, AppTech, NewLead, and FreeSeas are cited as examples of money laundering vehicles, with trading activity continuing for years after regulatory red flags were raised.

The document connects the alleged financial crimes to a network involving Michael Milken, his associates, and implies political connections through figures like Donald Trump, Jared Kushner, and Brad Parscale.
